name: Nicholas
comment info: Looking at the data, I see that the majority of Americans believe that congress should do more in response to global warming. Additionally, generally, fewer Americans believe that the president should do more to address global warming compared to congress, and putting the blame on their governor appears to be the middle ground between the other two options. I wonder why the data turned out to be this way. At first, I wondered why people were not putting more responsibility on the President, the person who is supposed to have all the influence. Upon further consideration, putting the responsibility on congress does make sense, as they ultimately have the most power, and if united for a particular cause (global warming), then they could get the most done to address climate change. I notice that throughout all three of the visuals, North Dakota, West Virginia, and Wyoming appear blue, meaning that at most, only 40-45% of the state’s population felt that their elected leaders should do more to address global warming. I wonder why these three states appear to be outliers; what separates them from the other 47 states? name: Max R
location: Miami Country Day School in Miami, Fl
comment info: When looking at the graph(s), I notice that an overwhelming high percentage of American people believe that congress should do more to address issues of global warming. ON the flip side of things, I observe that American's believe that the president should do the least, and thus be the least involved when it comes to issues regarding climate change. This was interesting, as I wonder why people shed the blame to congress at large rather than transitioning the blame to one singular individual. Human psychology suggests that when being hypercritical about generalized issues, people tend to shed the blame on one singular person representative of a larger social body. For instance, I am sure we have all heard "unemployment levels are high, it is person X's fault". Obviously said person is not sitting in their office, pressing buttons and making arrangements to increase the rate of unemployment, but serves a greater and more pertinent symbolic effect that America tends to elucidate. I am further curious to discover the reasons as to why so many American's feel like congress is at fault and should do more.

replies.name: S
replies.comment info: @Max R your "I wonder" statement and evidence made me look at the topic from a different point of view.

replies.name: F
replies.comment info: @Max R I absolutely agree with your point about placing the blame on individuals rather than larger groups, who may actually be more responsible for the problems surrounding our world today. It is much easier to say "It's the president's fault for climate change because of x.", mostly due to the fact that the president is the face of the United States. When referencing politics, he is the main component of the political body that we think about, therefore we perhaps subconsciously push the blame onto him when really we mean congress as a whole. This could be a reason why the majority of the country want less action from the president than congress or the governor.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Inabel 

Fellow New Jerseyan Inabel!  You have provided an interesting post here. 

One thing you wonder is, "... why the percentage of people in the nation relies more on the governor doing something about climate change rather than the actual president?"

In looking at what these images truly measure, I want to take you to our state of NJ. I'm sure know that the environment is a big issue in NJ (see our high percentages for wanting congress and the president to do more).  Yet when we look at the map regarding the governor, it doesn't seem to match.  Why is that? It isn't that Governor Murphy has done nothing for the environment (see recent grocery store plastic bag ban...and reactions to it).

name: Moderator Ben Kirk
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's live moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s maps show how Americans feel about their elected officials – President, Congressional representatives, governors and local officials, with regard to addressing global warming.  

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?”, “What do you wonder?"  and “How will this affect you?”  Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in these “graphs.” We look forward to replying to your discoveries.

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the online article that included these maps.  

Note that you can get a link to your response (and replies made to it) to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

Please visit our archive to see all graphs in this series (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphs).
View our archives that link to all past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), 
graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 
Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex).  

There will be no graph in the coming week.  The next “What’s Going On In This Graph?” will be released by Friday, Oct. 14 with moderation on Wednesday, Oct. 19.  The topic – immigration by country over time.  Keep noticing and wondering.
